item.title: Toyota has just announced a proprietary game engine, but that doesn't mean it's targeting PC and consoles
item.content:encoded:
It might have some juice.

Today, in news no one could've predicted: Toyota has been quietly working on a game engine of its own, but the end goal isn't what you'd expect.

The shocker comes from Automaton (with Japanese site Game*Spark as the original source), who explains Toyota Connected North America, a subsidiary of the company known for its cars, recently revealed the Fluorite engine. It "works closely with Flutter," which is the UI framework used by Google, and uses the Dart language to handle game logic as well as interface. "Its purpose is to yield high performance even on lower-end or embedded hardware, like running 3D graphics and interactive UI via in-vehicle systems."

At the time of writing, the official Fluorite site shared above is highlighting features like its high-performance Entity Component System (ECS) core, which is written in C++ and goes for "optimization for weaker hardware." Secondly, there are "model-defined trigger touch zones" that should allow artists to more easily set clickable areas inside Blender, making "building 3D interfaces a lot simpler."

The third highlight is "console-grade 3D rendering" powered by Google's Filament, which definitely ups its potential for game development even if Toyota's ambitions are limited to displays for its cars. Last but not least, Fluorite is also leaning on Flutter's 'Hot Reload' to allow quick updating of scenes.

So, why did Toyota work on this in the first place? Well, the original Game*Spark piece, translated by Automaton, explains Toyota Connected North America originally wanted to work with established game engines, but all of them were tied to high licensing fees or a resource-intensive nature. Thus, Fluorite was born.

The best part is that Fluorite is being marketed as a fully featured open-source engine, so even if Toyota won't be working on games, there might be potential there for independent developers.



https://www.eurogamer.net/toyota-fluorite-game-engine-reveal
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Indie dev claims the sudden takedown of its game was due to Warhammer creator Games Workshop, and a set of familiar-looking shoulder pads
item.content:encoded:
Tundra Interactive, the indie developer behind the indie strategy RPG Void War, has at last spoken out about why the game was temporarily removed from Steam earlier this year. The reason? Well, according to Tundra , it all has to do with a particular set of bulky, familiar-looking shoulder pads.

The original DMCA take down was issued by one Mal Reynolds on behalf of Games Workshop. Tundra initially believed this to be a troll takedown, given Mal Reynolds is the protagonist's name in Firefly, but it turns out this was a legitimate DMCA by the UK tabletop juggernaut.

Speaking to IGN, Tundra Interactive confirmed the DMCA's legitimacy, and claimed the given reason for the takedown notice was a pair of shoulder-pads shown off in its original featured trailer, described by Games Workshop as: "oversized convex shoulder pads with a metallic rim".

Looking at this character, and his shoulder pads, there is a clear resemblance between the bloke and a Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine. With the big spike attached, one could likely be mistaken for thinking it were a Chaos Astartes. Tundra told IGN it disagreed with this opinion from Games Workshop, but took the trailer off the Steam store page nonetheless .

In a statement issued to IGN, Tundra stated: "All of the artwork in the trailer is original work created by our artists. While we disagree with their assessment, the simplest way to get the game back up and avoid getting bogged down in DMCA process was to remove that trailer and move on. We may re-upload an updated version later after we find time to adjust that shot, but for now our priority is shipping content and finishing multi-language font support so we can finally deliver proper translations."

Regardless of this minor hurdle for Tundra and Void War, the game is back up on Steam seemingly unhampered by the DMCA notice, with a new trailer present to be safe. A word of warning perhaps, Games Workshop is keeping an eye out for potential copyright infringement! Be careful when designing grimdark sci-fi accessories for your bulky soldiers, folks.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/void-war-dmca-shoulder-pads-games-workshop-warhammer-40k

item.title: Watch Lady Gaga and Jigglypuff sing together in Pokémon's 30th anniversary Super Bowl spot
item.content:encoded:
Pokémon has never not been trendy, but we're expecting even more from the massive IP this year, as the "pocket monsters" are turning 30 later this month. That means there are game announcements on the horizon, celebrations happening all over, and even a huge Super Bowl spot starring Lady Gaga and other celebrities.

First teased last week, the 'What's Your Favorite?' ad played during last night's Super Bowl match and was also released online by The Pokémon Company, who enlisted a number of world-renowned individuals to essentially yap about their favourite Pokémon. The highlight here is Lady Gaga performing Jigglypuff's iconic song from the anime, but the whole thing feels adequately cute:

The list of celebrities in the spot includes comedian Trevor Noah, Blackpink's Jisoo, F1 driver Charles Leclerc, football player Lamine Yamal, actress Maitreyi Ramakrishnan, and singer Young Miko as they reveal their favourite Pokémon. You have safe picks like Arcanine and Jigglypuff, whereas others go for Zygarde or Luxray. No Pikachu here, which makes these clips feel somewhat genuine.

The end of the video also encourages Pokémon fans to create Pokémon 30 snapshots with the Pokémon GO app with a "What's Your Favorite" filter. Though this promo, which has cost The Pokémon Company millions of dollars just for the Super Bowl slot alone, focuses on the mobile sensation and people's connection with the largely adorable creatures, it's a fun way to kick off a "year of Pokémon" that probably has many surprises in store for us.

We're not expecting much talk of new games until after Pokémon Pokopia comes out early next month, but perhaps the 27th February (the day Pokémon Green & Red were originally released) will arrive with a stream that outlines the immediate future of Pokémon video games. That's just wishful thinking, but it would make sense, wouldn't it?

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/pokemon-30-super-bowl-spot-lady-gaga-and-jigglypuff-performance

item.title: Nioh 3 reaches almost 90,000 concurrent players on PC after launch, over doubling series record
item.content:encoded:
Initial player data indicates that Nioh 3 is performing well following its release last Friday, hitting nearly 90,000 concurrent players on Steam over the weekend. It is currently at the top of Steam's Trending Games list.

Nioh 3, the latest triple-A release from Team Ninja and Koei Tecmo, hit an all-time peak of 88,045 concurrent PC players on Sunday according to SteamDB. This is over double what Nioh 2 achieved on the same platform, and eight times what the original Nioh managed. The big difference, aside from a potential increase in popularity? Nioh 3 is the first game in the series to launch simultaneously on PC and console.

With that, it's worth considering Nioh 3 is also available on the PlayStation 5, so these figures are only one half of the whole picture. While player data isn't as readily available on console platforms, the game does currently have a 4.48 star rating on the PlayStation store.

It's not just a case of good-looking numbers, either. Nioh 3 is currently sitting on a very positive rating on Steam, with games critic reviews praising the game in droves. The game is currently sitting at 86 on Metacritic.

As for Eurogamer, it was described as "a historical high for Team Ninja" in our review. Dom Peppiat summarises the game's merits with the following: "Innovation is the ki to success for Team Ninja and Koei Tecmo, as Nioh 3 iterates on the formula once more to take an already great 'masocore' series to new heights."

Have you had a chance to check out Nioh 3 yet? Whether you have or not, you can read Eurogamers interview with general producer Yosuke Hayashi to learn more about the team's approach to difficulty in Nioh 3.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/nioh-3-reaches-almost-90000-concurrent-players-on-pc-after-launch-over-doubling-series-record
